chapter.htmlHeader: How is hepatitis B transmitted?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• In the UK, the majority (95%) of chronic hepatitis B infections occur in migrant populations, having been acquired perinatally in the country of birth.
  • Where new infections are acquired in adulthood, the source of infection is most commmonly via sexual contact or sharing of drug injecting equipment.
  • Transmission by blood-to-blood contact:
    • Sharing of drug injecting equipment
      • Use of injected drugs is the biggest risk factor for new infection in the UK.
      • The virus can persist outside the body indefinitely.
    • Occupational hazards
      • These include needlestick injuries or direct exposure of mucous membranes or breaks in the skin (including the eyes or, rarely, following bites) to infected blood.
    • Blood transfusions and blood products
      • The risk of contracting hepatitis B from blood products in the UK has been virtually eliminated.
      • People who receive blood transfusions from some other countries may continue to be at risk.
    • Tattoos, body piercing, or acupuncture
      • There is a risk of transmission if equipment is not sterile. People carrying out these procedures are also considered to potentially be at risk.
    • Household contact and sharing of toiletry items
      • Hepatitis B is not spread through food or water, sharing eating utensils, hugging, kissing, hand holding, coughing, or sneezing.
      • Occasionally, infection may be transmitted via a household or casual contact, including by direct contact between young children in the home or at childcare facilities.
      • There is a risk from sharing items such as toothbrushes and razors.
      • In hyper-endemic areas, chronically infected children can inadvertently contaminate environmental surfaces with cuts or open sores, leading to horizontal transmission.
  • Sexual transmission
    • Transmission occurs via mucous membranes (vaginal, anal, and oral) during sex.
    • People having unprotected sex (vaginal, anal, or oral) or having multiple partners are at greatest risk.
  • Mother-to-baby transmission
    • Perinatal transmission (during childbirth) is common in areas of high prevalence. However, mother-to-baby transmission has been reduced by the universal vaccination programme recommended by the World Health Organization.
    • Transmission to the unborn fetus is relatively uncommon (accounting for less than 5% of mother-to-baby transmissions).
    • Hepatitis B cannot be transmitted to infants during breastfeeding (unless nipples are cracked or bleeding).

[NICE, 2013; NICE, 2014; Sundaram and Kowdley, 2015; British Liver Trust, 2017; PHE, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018; NaTHNac, 2019]
